author: rabbitholepools
title: Cardano Social Enterprises
description: How can Cardano Catalyst create maximum positive impact through blockchain-powered Social Enterprise?

f6_assessments.q0: One of Cardano´s main goals is to help and aid the development of opportunities in developing countries of the world. While there are and have been geographical Challenges aimed at this, including Cardano´s traditional focus on Africa, the matter of the fact is that the other side of this focus must be raising social awareness and aiding social entrepreneurs who employ Cardano to help them reach their goals. In this sense, social enterprises that can make the world a better place at the same time as help onboard projects and members throughout the world deserve the support of the Cardano Community.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers have a history of engagement with the Community and multiple proposals already submitted, always centered on social engagement as an area ripe for Cardano development, as well as with stakepool operation. The amount of comments, feedback and constructive criticism, as well as proactive engagement and inclusion of new Community members as co-proposers, is a clear indicator that this proposal team will generate a positive environment for the aiding and supporting of proposals within their Challenge setting.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs presented (number of social entrepreneurs becoming proposers, Cardano-based social innovations, existing social businesses adopting Cardano, lowered admin fees for social enterprises, etc.) seem aptly chosen. However, it would also be interesting to be able to use as KPIs the increase in volume of Cardano transactions due to social enterprises onboarded, the increase of SPOs with ESG goals or compliance, amongst others.

f6_assessments.q0: IMO the proposal has the potential to have a lot of positive impact towards both society (by supporting social enterprises) and towards the cardano ecosystem (by extending the blockchain into new areas. As for Cardanos mission, it aligns well with it, as part of Cardanos mission is to expand usecases of blockchain beyond those of financial gain.
f6_assessments.q1: I believe the Cardano community has a lot of potential to adress this challenge, as there have already been several proposals in that area in the past. A credible challenge team of people that are already active within the community is in place and will most likely steward the challenge wuite well. The challenge is set up in a way that welcomes a wide variety of solutions in a clearly defined scope.
f6_assessments.q2: The challenge metrics are open enough to welcome a variety of solutions, while at the same time they still have set a common framework for proposals to fulfill in order to make them fit into the challenge. I think this is the perfect balance to allow creative solutions in a clearly defined scope and the metrics will allow for a variety auf auditable solutions. I really like that you have defined some points that every proposal needs to fulfill.

f6_assessments.q0:
This challenge is for social enterprises seeking to build on Cardano. I rate alignment based on two sets of metrics: the fund9 strategic goals and the guiding questions for challenge setting.

This challenge prepares groups of people to contribute to the ecosystem but only not indirectly addresses the other two strategic goals (albeit to some extent app development). To some extent it may help open sourcing, but only insofar as business choose that route. It is however,  something that could be a springboard for broader adoption if it succeeds. Existing businesses will onboard their users to Cardano and hence gain wider adoption. It is also something that is likely to gain voter’s engagement because social missions motivate people. Hence this challenge receives the full 5 stars.
f6_assessments.q1: The funding request is moderate in size, $500k, and given the popularity of Business solutions and the many mission-driven proposals I have seen as a CA from the past two funds, I believe there is capacity in the community to meet this challenge. Numerous examples in the community including littercoin, Waya, World Mobile and Empowa illustrate this power of the Cardano community - which is sure to spill over and attract projects and teams across the world with similar ambitions. The proposing team include both a single stake pool operator with research background and an active CA community contributor Tomi Astikainen who has extensive experience in strategic management consulting. I am fuly confident that they would constitute an excellent challenge team sheparding teams in this challenge!
f6_assessments.q2: They offer 5 key metrics. Including number of entrepreneurs and other measurable metrics such as lowered admin fees for enterprises. These are well defined. Moreover, they also include recommendations for proposers in a very detailed manner, e.g. “It is recommended that the proposers include a "triple bottom line", measuring impact on People, Planet and Profits.” and that measurement should be done over time: now, short term, long term.

f6_assessments.q0: I have been fascinated by the subject of social enterprises for a long time. I believe that the key to human survival is promoting the growth of businesses that seek to contribute to society with a balanced approach to the welfare of individuals, societies, and the planet. Given that Cardano aims to be a social and financial operating system that will enable the construction of alternatives to traditional financial services, it is evident that the two are aligned. I would recommend that the team improve the description of the challenge question, as it appeared that it would only be relevant to the Catalyst ecosystem when Cardano as an ecosystem in general has the potential for impact sought. In fact, the question asked in the challenge brief would be more appropriate as the first question. A second element that would enhance this challenge would be the inclusion of potential directions that potential proposers can pursue, since this is a new challenge and it would be appropriate to give a more specific direction. As for the alignment with the strategic goals, I can see a distinct alignment with regard to the metric that seeks to prepare people to contribute to the ecosystem, as well as with regard to the evolution of the development ecosystem. Having said that, regarding the rationale given by the challenge team in regards to the open source topic, I believe that a more significant effort could have been made in the description of the challenge settings, so that there is a more explicit alignment regarding the requirements of potential challenge proposers.
f6_assessments.q1: There is a lot of experience in the Catalyst and Cardano community in general. Actually, I believe that we already have several use cases within the community that fit the requirements of this challenge, so in terms of our capacity to address it, I don't anticipate any difficulties. A further positive aspect is that there are already two people as part of the challenge team in case the challenge is selected. Concerning the budget requested to be allocated to the challenge, I must admit that I would have allocated a little less in order to test the responsiveness of the community, while at the same time having a moderate budget to limit the risk of inefficient allocation of resources. However, I generally agree from the standpoint of feasibility.
f6_assessments.q2: The definition of success criteria seems appropriate to me, however, the set of success metrics could have been specified more clearly since many of them are not measurable. Additionally, metrics should also have been added to measure a clear alignment with Cardano as a blockchain. I believe that the considerations described after the success metrics add value from an auditability standpoint and will ultimately assist the community when audit exercises are undertaken after funds have been allocated.

f6_assessments.q0:
Cardano has a greater social appeal than most other blockchains and the fact that Cardano puts a governance layer on the protocol layer, unlike Ethereum for example, makes the community more active, Catalyst itself is proof community involvement and how challenges related to social causes have been approved.

Despite the proposal to articulate alignment with the Catalyst Fund9 Challenge Setting Strategic Goals, there is no direct alignment. In theory any challenge could have an indirect impact with the Catalyst Fund9 Challenge Setting Strategic Goals, the point is if the challenge is directly addressing one of the 3 defined items and in this case it is not.

There are challenges fully dedicated to the "developer ecosystem" or "dapps & integrations", or fully dedicated to encouraging contributors in the ecosystem (CAs, toolmakers...) or fully dedicated to open source solutions, so I cannot give the same weight to the alignment of the Catalyst Fund9 Challenge Setting Strategic Goals with this challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
This is a new challenge, so there is no previous parameter to facilitate the demand assessment, but the topic addressed in the challenge has been addressed by several proposals since Fund2 and the topic is not associated with technical complexities that would limit the pool of potential proposers then I believe that the community has the capacity to meet the challenge.

Despite the low technical complexity, there is an overlap of the scope of these challenges with other Catalyst challenges, which can decrease the demand for this challenge and empty the competition, decreasing the quality of the proposals in general.

There is already a challenge team defined, which is an additional point.
f6_assessments.q2:
The definition of success is subjective.
"New Social Enterprises being brought to life and existing ones renewing their business models through Cardano adoption."

What does "brought to life" mean?

Considering the description of the challenge, any proposal funded in this challenge would be considered an enterprise/social business and, consequently, would be making the challenge a success even if the proposals did not have a relevant impact.

I would recommend that the team establish a more tangible definition so that it is possible to understand if the challenge was a success or not.

Number of Social entrepreneurs becoming proposers in Fund9
Cardano-based social innovations delivering meaningful change
Existing social businesses adopting Cardano
Lowered admin fees for Social Enterprises
Social enterprise project affecting people, community or environments positively

5 key metrics were defined for performance evaluation, they are appropriate metrics to measure the number of projects created and migrated to Cardano, however the metrics could be more objective regarding the quality of the outcome. ("meaningful change" and "affecting people, community or environments positively" are not very effective definitions to indicate performance in the challenge.)

In addition to the 5 key metrics, suggestions were made for items to indicate alignment/performance/auditability that end up improving the performance/auditability assessment of the challenge.

f6_assessments.q0:
Promoting and expanding entrepeneurship among Cardano community is key for blockchain technology to become more and more present in people lives, once real applications become available more rapidly. Therefore, I completely agree that this challenge is key for Cardano to reach its mission and consolidate itself even more. Moreover, as explained in the proposal body, it aligns with the 3 strategic goals of F9.

Besides this, Challenge structure is very well written and clearly provide directions to future proposers. It defines also its scopes, aiming to reach both new businesses/enteprises and expanding efforts on existing one. I also appreciate the focus on social and enviromental aspects, which makes it very aligned with UN SDGs.
f6_assessments.q1:
Cardano community is totally capable of addressing this challenge given that there are already several companies that were born from other Catalyst initiatives. Moreover, its possible to see sustainability and social aspects being more present in the proposals each fund. Having a dedicated challenge for this will certainly boost these iniativies.

Extra points here for having already a committed challenge team, with experience in blockchain and entrepreneurship.
f6_assessments.q2:
It is provided 5 good and sensible kpis to measure challenge progress towards addressing the issue. The only point for me is that kpi number 2 (Cardano-based social innovations delivering meaningful change) seems a little subjective and meaninful change could be better defined. This is just a tiny detail though.
Besides the metrics, swome guidelines for proposers that will certainly help to improve the metrics and facilitates the measurements are provided.
One extra kpi that could be added here would be related to a variety of regions in the world creating or adopting Cardano solutions in its businesses. It is imporant to cardano to expand its global reach,

f6_assessments.q0: Cardano Catalyst is the blockchain which seeks to create positive impact within the technology by adapting and bring on board different businesses for sustainable. This challenge team fits into the general overview of the Cardano mission
f6_assessments.q1: A walk through the ecosystem proves that several expertise exits to develop proposal to this challenge team to explore the use of the blockchain technology in other ways.
f6_assessments.q2: The knowledge of the advocates of the challenge team is quite broad and will really guide proposers to do the right thing. Though the funds requested looks a little small, but for the first time of the challenge it is acceptable

importance: Powering existing and starting Social Enterprises with blockchain and introducing new types of social innovations can supercharge progress.
success: New Social Enterprises being brought to life and existing ones renewing their business models through Cardano adoption.
